oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1867 Map of Mamaroneck, Scarsdale, White Plains, Harrison, and Rye
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Beers, F.W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1867 Map of Mamaroneck, Scarsdale, White Plains, Harrison, and Rye
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Quinn, Edythe Ann. Freedom Journey: Black Civil War Soldiers and The Hills Community, Westchester County, New York, Albany: State University of New York Press, c2015, gallery 1.
The map is at the Westchester County Historical Society.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Closeup of The Hills Community as Shown in 1867 Beers Map.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Beers, F.W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Close-up showing Stony Hill Road, the principle area of settlement in the Harrison section of The Hills". The names of the property owners are shown on the map.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Quinn, Edythe Ann. Freedom Journey: Black Civil War Soldiers and The Hills Community, Westchester County, New York, Albany: State University of New York Press, c2015, gallery 2.
The map is at the Westchester County Historical Society.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of a Town: 1790
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States Census Bureau
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: 1790 Census
The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is the first United States Census information for the Town of Harrison, New York, dated 1790. It gives family names and corresponding data for each family. Highlighted are the names of "All other free persons" and the number of free people in their households. The name Zingo referred to Zingo Stout, whom Dr. Edythe A. Quinn considered the African founding father of The Hills.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Heads of Families At The First Census Of The United States Taken In The Year 1790 New York. Government Printing Office, Washington D.C., c1907, p.199.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Zing(o) Stout
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States Census Bureau
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: 1810 Census
The Hills Harrison New York
Stout, Zing(o)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dr. Edythe Ann Quinn credits Zingo Stout as being the African founding father of The Hills. "Interestingly, among Hills residents from 1810 forward, most have Christian or English common names and surnames; an exception being Zingo Stout who retained his African given name."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Quinn, Edythe Ann. Freedom Journey: Black Civil War Soldiers and The Hills Community, Westchester County, New York, Albany: State University of New York Press, c2015, p.158.
Courtesy of Ancestry.com
Original data: Third Census of the United States, 1810. (NARA microfilm publication M252, 71 rolls). Bureau of the Census, Record Group 29. National Archives, Washington, D.C.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Keeping Records: "Teacher's Wages Due on Colored People's Children..."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: School Report, 1839 District No. 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This document shows the names of the parents of the twelve black students attending school from April 8th through August 8th, 1839. Included are the number of days each student attended and the amount of fees due to the School District.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The Freeholders and Inhabitants of the School District No.1
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Research Courtesy of Edythe Ann Quinn, Ph.D.
The original document is at the Harrison Historical Society at the Charles Dawson History Center.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "...To Be A Church..."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Office of the Westchester County Clerk
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Purdy, Charles A.
Methodist Episcopal Zion Church
Halstead, Aaron
Hatfield, Moses
Seymour, Alfred
Seamore, Henry
Cornell, Daniel
The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Five Hills residents acting as trustees of Methodist Episcopal Zion Church agreed to a mortgage with Charles A. Purdy for a quarter of an acre land. "The money borrowed in this mortgage may have been used to finance the building of a modest church on the property".
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Quinn, Edythe Ann. Freedom Journey: Black Civil War Soldiers and The Hills Community, Westchester County, New York, Albany: State University of New York Press, c2015, p.12
The Westchester County Archives, Liber of Mortgages, No. 88. p.183-185
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Beginning at the Red Oak Tree: Buying Land
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Office of the Westchester County Clerk
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Anderson, Hagar
Mitchell, Jeremiah
The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This deed shows the purchase of real property by Jeremiah Mitchell, "a founding member of The Hills community", in 1815. "Ownership of property was one of the most important factors in the stability of "The Hills" community".
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Quinn, Edythe Ann. Freedom Journey: Black Civil War Soldiers and The Hills Community, Westchester County, New York, Albany: State University of New York Press, c2015, p.11
The Westchester County Archives, Liber of Deeds, No. 37, p.286
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "...In a Place Commonly Called the Hills...": Buying Land
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Office of the Westchester County Clerk
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mitchell, Jeremiah
Tierce, William
The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This deed shows the purchase of real property in 1851 by William Tierce, a Hills resident and father of Civil War soldiers Simeon Anderson Tierce and Solomon Tierce. This is one of several real estate transactions William Tierce entered into with other blacks in The Hills.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Research Courtesy of Edythe Ann Quinn, Ph.D.
The Westchester County Archives, Liber of Deeds, No. 159, p. 32
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Peak of the Hills
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States Census Bureau
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: 1860 U.S. Census
The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "In the early 1860s, The Hills was at its peak as a northern, black community" and represented the largest concentration of African Americans in Westchester County. The data shown here represents the Harrison section of the Hills area.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Quinn, Edythe Ann. Freedom Journey: Black Civil War Soldiers and The Hills Community, Westchester County, New York, Albany: State University of New York Press, c2015, p.9
Courtesy of Ancestry.com
Original data: 1860 U.S. census, population schedule. NARA microfilm publication M653, 1,438 rolls. Washington, D.C.: National Archives and Records Administration, n.d.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "My Dear Wife..." Letters from a Civil War Soldier
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Sergeant Simeon A. Tierce
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Tierce, Sergeant Simeon Anderson
Tierce, [Depau, Depew], Sarah Jane
The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sergeant Simeon Anderson Tierce was a Hills resident and a Civil War Soldier. His eloquent letters were written to his wife, Sarah Jane, while serving in the Civil War. Evident in his writing are his love and concern for his family, friends, and neighbors in The Hills community. He described life as a soldier, the living conditions, work duties, illness, and death. Transcriptions are courtesy of Dr. Edythe A. Quinn, who discovered the letters during her research at the National Archives.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Quinn, Edythe Ann. Freedom Journey: Black Civil War Soldiers and The Hills Community, Westchester County, New York, Albany: State University of New York Press, c2015, Appendix B, p.133-148
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Simeon A. Tierce's letters are stored at the National Archives and Records Administration under the Federal Pension Records, 1861-1934 "Widow's Pension Claim, Case of Sarah Jane [Tierce] Depau, No. 257.715." [also spelled Depew]. Copies of the handwritten letters and transcriptions are from the Westchester County Archives’ website http://www.westchesterarchives.com/CW/Thumbnails/Tierce_letters_th.htm
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Changes 1880
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States Census Bureau
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Tierce, William
Depew, Sarah Jane
Barker, Benjamin
Barker, David
1880 Census
The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "The 1880 census revealed demographic changes that would affect the long-term stability of The Hills community, for example, the aging population, the number of widows, and more irregularly structured households".
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Quinn, Edythe Ann. Freedom Journey: Black Civil War Soldiers and The Hills Community, Westchester County, New York, Albany: State University of New York Press, c2015, p.116-117
Courtesy of Ancestry.com
Original data: Tenth Census of the United States, 1880. (NARA microfilm publication T9, 1,454 rolls). Records of the Bureau of the Census, Record Group 29. National Archives, Washington, D.C.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A Well Deserved Pension At Last!
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Barker, Elisha
The Hills Harrison New York
White Plains, NY.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This article describes some of the Barker family history. The family was among the first to settle in The Hills. Three brothers served in Civil War. Elisha Barker, a disabled veteran and the last of the three Barker brothers, received his pension after many years of waiting.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Alvah French Scrapbooks, Volume 20, page 36. The Westchester County Archives. Quinn, Edythe Ann. Freedom Journey: Black Civil War Soldiers and The Hills Community, Westchester County, New York, Albany: State University of New York Press, c2015, p.121
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Earning an Honest Penny
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: V. M. Hodgson
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Depeau (var, Depew), Sarah Jane (Tierce)
Tierce, Simeon A. [Anderson]
The Hills Harrison New York
Hodgson, V.M.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In her application for a widow’s pension, Sarah Jane Tierce testified concerning the work history of her late husband, Sergeant Simeon A. [Anderson] Tierce, 14th Rhode Island Heavy Artillery Regiment (11th Regiment, USCT). V. M. Hodgson, who filed this affidavit, served as the Pension Agent in White Plains for Sarah Jane and other members of The Hills community.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Sarah Jane (Tierce) Depeau (var, Depew), Widow’s Pension Claim, National Archives and Records Administration
Research Courtesy of Edythe Ann Quinn, Ph.D.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: On the Death of Her Husband Simeon
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Sarah Jane (Tierce) Depeau (var, Depew)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Depeau (var, Depew), Sarah Jane (Tierce)
Tierce, Simeon A. [Anderson]
The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In her application for a widow’s pension, Sarah Jane Tierce wrote a letter to the U.S. Pension Office concerning the death of her husband, Simeon A. [Anderson] Tierce on July 7, 1864. This letter also demonstrates Sarah Jane’s literacy, especially her good handwriting and composition.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Sarah Jane (Tierce) Depeau (var, Depew), Widow’s Pension Claim, National Archives and Records Administration
Research Courtesy of Edythe Ann Quinn, Ph.D.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "We were school boys together"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Thomas L. Brown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Brown, Thomas L.
Tierce, Solomon
The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In support of his friend Solomon Tierce’s application for a Civil War veteran’s pension based on illness and financial need, Thomas L. Brown gave a deposition explaining how he knew Solomon from their school years together in The Hills. Brown and Tierce served together in the 29th Connecticut Infancy Regiment, Colored Volunteers, in the Civil War. Brown also explained his own work as a peddler.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Solomon Tierce, Veteran’s Pension Claim, National Archives and Records Administration Quinn, Edythe Ann. Freedom Journey: Black Civil War Soldiers and The Hills Community, Westchester County, New York, Albany: State University of New York Press, c2015, p.14
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Happy Birthday Mr. Seymour!
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Seymour, Harvey
The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This article cites one of The Hills residents, Mr. Harvey Seymour, turning ninety eight in 1903. Harvey Seymour married Jane Halstead on Feb. 25 1835, and they bought land in The Hills which he farmed. His son, William Henry Seymour served in the 14th Rhode Island Heavy Artillery Regiment (11th USCT), returned to The Hills after the war, died of dysentery in March 1866, and was buried in Stony Hill Cemetery with a military marker. Harvey and Jane Seymour are also buried in Stony Hill Cemetery.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Alvah French Scrapbooks, Volume 15, page 91. The Westchester County Archives
Research Courtesy of Edythe Ann Quinn, Ph.D.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Farming in the Hills
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Harvey Seymour
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Seymour, Harvey
The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In support of his wife Jane’s claim for a mother’s pension after their son’s death from dysentery contracted during the Civil War, Harvey Seymour gave a deposition describing how he farmed and the annual tax on his acre of land in The Hills. Their son, William Henry Seymour served in the 14th Rhode Island Heavy Artillery Regiment (11th USCT), returned to The Hills after the war, died of dysentery in March 1866, and was buried in Stony Hill Cemetery with a military marker.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Jane Seymour, Pension Claim, National Archives and Records Administration. Quinn, Edythe Ann. Freedom Journey: Black Civil War Soldiers and The Hills Community, Westchester County, New York, Albany: State University of New York Press, c2015, p.14
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Married in 1835
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Rev. R. W. Harris
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Seymour, Harvey
Seymour, Jane
The Hills Harrison New York
Grace Church, White Plains, NY.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Rev. R. W. Harris was Rector of the Grace [Episcopal] Church, White Plains New York. Jane Gaul was born Jane Halstead; her stepfather was David Gaul, a founding member of The Hills community; more often she gave her name as Jane Halstead. She married Harvey Seymour of The Hills on Feb. 25, 1835 in Grace Church, White Plains, NY. A copy of their marriage record was submitted to the Pension Board in support of Jane’s Application for a mother’s pension on the death of their son William Henry Seymour who served in the 14th Rhode Island Heavy Artillery Regiment (11th USCT), returned to The Hills after the war, and died of dysentery in March 1866.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Jane Seymour, Pension Claim, National Archives and Records Administration
Research Courtesy of Edythe Ann Quinn, Ph.D.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: 1911 Bromley Map: Part of the Towns of Harrison & Rye
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: G. W. Bromley
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: The Hills Harrison New York
Sarah Depew
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1911 Close-up showing Stony Hill, the principle area of settlement in the Harrison section of The Hills. The name Sarah Depew refers to the widow of Civil War soldier Sergeant Simeon Anderson Tierce.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: The Harrison Historical Society at the Charles Dawson History Center
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sissy...Sarah Watson
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: New York Department of State
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Watson, Sarah
Tierce, Sergeant Simeon Anderson
Depew, Sarah Jane
1925 Census
The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sarah Watson was the stepdaughter of Civil War Soldier Sergeant Simeon Anderson Tierce. He fondly referred to her as “Sissy” or “Sis” in his Civil War letters to her mother. "I want you to have that place fixed so that if me or you should die, it will always be a good home for Sis as long as she lives." This 1925 Census showed that Sarah Watson still lived in the Hills.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: New York State Government Printing Office
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Quinn, Edythe Ann. Freedom Journey: Black Civil War Soldiers and The Hills Community, Westchester County, New York, Albany: State University of New York Press, c2015, p.124-125
Microfilm is stored at the Westchester County Archives

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Silver Lake Preserve
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Westchester County Park and Recreation Commissions Annual Report
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Silver Lake Park
Silver Lake Preserve
Westchester County Park Commission
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This annual report shows the acquisition of lands necessary for planned Westchester County park and parkway projects. By 1928 in order to establish the Silver Lake Preserve, the commission purchased 427 acres of land "from property owners, both whites and blacks, in this corner of the county where White Plains, Harrison, and North Castle come together, including The Hills land."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Westchester County Parks Commission 1928 Annual Report, page 10
Courtesy of the Westchester County Archives
Quinn, Edythe Ann. Freedom Journey: Black Civil War Soldiers and The Hills Community, Westchester County, New York, Albany: State University of New York Press, c2015, p.125
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Resting Place
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Works Progress Administration (WPA)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Buckhout Road Cemetery
Stony Hill Road Cemetery
Civil War Veterans
Asbury Colored People's Church
The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This map shows the burial sites of thirteen Civil War veterans from The Hills. These site numbers correspond to each veteran’s cemetery record. From the United States Navy: Aaron Halstead, Jr. 8023.20. From the Fourteenth Rhode Island Regiment, Heavy Artillery, Colored Volunteers (Eleventh USCT): Benjamin Barker 8020.20, David Barker 8016.20, William H. Brooks 8018.20, Joseph Griffin 8017.20, Alfred Seymour 8021.20, and William Henry Seymour (both var. Seymore) 8022.20 . From the Twenty-ninth Connecticut Regiment, Infantry, Colored Volunteers: Thomas Butler 8015.20, John C. Lockwood 8019.20, Robert Odell Mitchell 8011.20, and John Purdy 8012.20; and from the Twentieth Regiment, Infantry, USCT: William Purdy 8014.20 and John Brown 8013.20. Asbury Colored People’s Church, the site of The Hills church, is shown next to the cemetery map.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: http://collections.westchestergov.com/cdm/singleitem/collection/vetcards/id/1635/rec/1 The Harrison Historical Society at the Charles Dawson History Center, under Cemetery- Stony Hill file. A copy of the map was donated by Barbara L. Bush-James, October 1996.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Stony Hill Cemetery
Buckout Road Cemetery
The Hills Harrison New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1999, the Stony Hill Cemetery, receiving national recognition, became listed on the National Register of Historic Places, as indicated in this letter from Ruth L. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Poster of Parsons Memorial School Presentation and Dedication
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Parsons Memorial School
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "In finely written hand, extremely tiny, are listed the presidents of the United States, the States of the Union, the names of the pupils in the school according to grade, a picture of John Parsons, and Parsons’ presentation speech, and an article “The Grand Monument” (a description of the school and the gifts). A poem is also written in the same calligraphy. It was written for the occasion."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: The Harrison Historical Society at the Charles Dawson History Center

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Louis M. Klein
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Harrison High School
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Klein, Louis M.
Parsons Memorial School
Harrison High School
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Louis M. Klein came to Parsons in 1929 when he was hired as a teacher of English and Spanish. In 1934 he became principal of Harrison High School and Superintendent of Schools in 1936. In his 34 years of service as Superintendent "he oversaw increasing enrollment in the schools, huge expenditures on new buildings and students going off to three wars",said Donald Howard, School Superintendent in 2001. The Louis M. Klein Middle School is named in his honor.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Reminiscence: Harrison High School Yearbook 1936
The Harrison Historical Society at the Charles Dawson History Center
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Eugene J. Feeley
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Harrison High School
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Feeley, Eugene J.
Harrison High School
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eugene Feely was the first male teacher in the Harrison School district, joining the staff in 1927. He was a physical education instructor, coached all sports and taught all grades from K-12. In his 37 years of service he also served as principal of several schools in the district. The athletic field behind Harrison Avenue School was dedicated in his honor in 1964. The Feely Scholarship fund was renamed in his honor as its founder in 1966.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Reminiscence: Harrison High School Yearbook 1931. The Harrison Historical Society at the Charles Dawson History Center
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This material may be protected by the U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.). Fair use of this content is permitted as defined by copyright law. Responsibility for determining fair use lies with the user. The user is responsible for any claims that may arise.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Memories of Parsons"
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Westmoreland, Gene
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Parsons Memorial School
Westmoreland, Gene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This book is a memoir and a brief history of Parsons Memorial School written for the 50th reunion of the Harrison High School Class of 1961. It covers the school from its beginning in 1898, the two expansions in 1908 and 1928, its name changes, and key faculty.The many photos in the book include the ceremonial key presented by John Parsons at the dedication in 1898, the original building in 1898 and the school as it looked after each expansion.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Westmoreland, Gene. “Memories of Parsons” and A Brief History of Parsons Memorial School, Gene Westmoreland Golf Services LLC, 2011
The physical book is stored at the Harrison Public Library

Parsons Memorial School
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This original document is the program for the eighth grade graduation held on Monday June 24, 1912.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Maroon Murmurs
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Editor in Chief Eleanor Dodd
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Harrison High School
Parsons School
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is the inaugural issue of the Harrison High School newspaper called Maroon Murmurs. The graduating class was the largest one in the history of the school up to 1937. Ninety students received diplomas.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Honoring Roswell R. Marshall
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Rotary Club
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Marshall, Roswell
Parsons Memorial School
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a program of the Testimonial Dinner Dance held for Roswell R. Marshall. Roswell Marshall, who was named Harrison’s first Citizen of the Year in 1983, came to Parsons in 1937. He taught English, Drama and Public Speaking. He was principal of Parsons Memorial School from 1950-1969.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Printed by Aranac Printing, Inc. Harrison, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: The Harrison Historical Society at the Charles Dawson History Center, under Marshall, Roswell R. file

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Harrison High School
Class of 1937
Senior Day
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The first Harrison High School Senior Day was held on April 21, 1937. Described here is the conception of the idea and it’s implementation, including quotes from participating students.
